channel.title: Projects on Jeff Sawalha
channel.description: Recent content in Projects on Jeff Sawalha

item.title: Project # 2: Predicting pediatric anxiety from the temporal pole using neural responses to emotional faces
item.description: The second project involved functional neuroimaging for children suffering from anxiety disorders. Specifically, this was a dataset of 45 children (aged 5-9), who were shown images of fearful, angry and neutral faces, while they were under an fMRI scanner. Our goal was to classify anxious and non-anxious children based strictly on their neuroimaging data. Using advanced computational algorithms, we were successfully able to classify children with various anxiety disorders. More interestingly, our model identified a relatively unknown area of the brain that best distinguished these individuals.

item.title: Project # 1: Individualized identification of first-episode bipolar disorder using machine learning and cognitive tests
item.description: This was a publication examining neurocognitive data in patients with bipolar I disorder (BD). We wanted to examine the correlation between certain neurocognitive deficits and the number of manic / psychotic episodes in first-episode and chronic-BD participants (FE-BD & CHR-BD). The overall objective of this study was to identify individuals who are in the beginning stages of bipolar disorder by learning the more nuanced cognitive deficits that CHR-BD participantâ€™s display in their neurocognitive tests.

item.title: Project # 3: X-ray classification of pneumonia
item.description: Here, I obtained a dataset from a popular website called Kaggle. Here, there are over 5000 images of chest x-rays, and half are suffering from pneumonia. The performance task was simple: Train a classifier that can detect which x-rays represent pneumonia patients. Here is a list of skills I deployed for this project: Used PyTorch to train a convolutional neural network (CNN) Standardized x-ray images, which included: resizing, centering, randomized horizontal skips, randomized rotations, randomized gray scaling, and tensor transformations Achieved a balanced accuracy of 82% Above is an array of x-ray images

item.title: Project # 4: Detecting presence of PTSD using sentiment analysis from text data
item.description: Sentiment analysis refers to the use of natural language processing to extract emotional content from text information. In our paper, we train a machine learning model on textual data, to identify individuals with PTSD using sentiment analysis from semi-structured interviews. Our sample size included 188 individuals without PTSD, and 87 with PTSD. The interview was conducted by an artificial character (Ellie) over a video-conference call. Our model was able to achieve a balanced accuracy of 80.
